issue.title: [Python] Timeline for dropping Python 2.7 support
issue.body:
***Note**: This issue was originally created as [ARROW-331](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-331). Please see the [migration documentation](https://gist.github.com/toddfarmer/12aa88361532d21902818a6044fda4c3) for further details.*

### Original Issue Description:
I'd be in favor of dropping 2.7 support altogether from pyarrow, `[~xhochy]` what do you think?

comments.body:
***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-331?focusedCommentId=15562652) by Uwe Korn (uwe):*
I oppose that as I'm stuck with 2.7 for a bit. I'm a big fan of advancing but sadly it's not easy always :'(

***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-331?focusedCommentId=15562962) by Wes McKinney (wesm):*
OK good to know. I'll put this on my "wishlist" for now

***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-331?focusedCommentId=15818757) by Wes McKinney (wesm):*
It seems it'll be in our interest to maintain Python 2.7 support probably until end of 2018 at least.

***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-331?focusedCommentId=16529260) by Wes McKinney (wesm):*
We should think about when we want to drop Python 2.7 support. Probably the earliest we could drop it would be January 2019. Do we need/want to wait longer?

***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-331?focusedCommentId=16529471) by Uwe Korn (uwe):*
Pandas and NumPy drop it January 2019, so Arrow should probably follow.

***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-331?focusedCommentId=16530338) by Wes McKinney (wesm):*
Great, sounds good to me.

***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-331?focusedCommentId=16643452) by Antoine Pitrou (apitrou):*
Are we still on track to drop 2.7 support next January? AFAICT this means we'll release 0.12.0 and perhaps 0.13.0 with 2.7 support still, then will drop it entirely.

***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-331?focusedCommentId=16643475) by Wes McKinney (wesm):*
Good question. I recall an e-mail thread somewhere where we discussed pushing until end of 2019, will have to dig it up. According to https://anaconda.org/conda-forge/pyarrow/files, we still have a pretty good amount of 2.7 installs, more than 3.5, but 1/4 as many as 3.6.

***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-331?focusedCommentId=16696242) by Wes McKinney (wesm):*
Seems like we should make a decision about this and make some kind of public statement in our documentation to close this issue. It seems that the conservative option would be to support 2.7 through end of 2019

***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-331?focusedCommentId=16697078) by Antoine Pitrou (apitrou):*
I think `[~kszucs]` has been the one doing the most work on the Python side recently.

***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-331?focusedCommentId=16761412) by Wes McKinney (wesm):*
Shall we make a public statement about this in the documentation as a way to close this? I think realistically we need to support Python 2.7 through the end of 2019. It'll be here before we know it

***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-331?focusedCommentId=16761680) by Antoine Pitrou (apitrou):*
That sounds like a good idea. "Until the end of 2019" sounds ok too.

***Note**: [Comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-331?focusedCommentId=16765248) by Antoine Pitrou (apitrou):*
Issue resolved by pull request 3609
<https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3609>
